The bell tolls six, the knell of parting day,</br>To spend the ev'ning patriot souls agree,</br>Illuminations brighten o'er the way,</br>And bid the dim ey'd sons of faction flee.
Here Wilkes and Liberty is heard abroad,</br>There Glyn and Freedom shake the ambient air,</br>Here slily filchers of the eve maraud,</br>The English smile, and envious Scotsmen stare:
Save that in yonder quiet silent place,</br>A wary Scot employs Astrea's scales,</br>Impartially examines either case,</br>And finds true freedom in the south prevails.
Beneath these plain and feet-oppressed stones,</br>Now undistinguish'd in promiscuous heap,</br>Industrious citizens, and lazy drones,</br>The surly fathers of the parish, sleep.
The hoarse, rough chimney-sweeping call of morn,</br>Or shriller tenor of the milk maid's note;</br>The brick-dust ass's bray — the mail-cart horn</br>No more shall rouse them with the varied throat.
For them no more shall toasted muffins smoke,</br>The dreaded task no more the 'prentice fear;</br>No more their dames their horned foreheads stroke,</br>Nor children tremble at their brow severe.
Yet those shall live, in memory at least,</br>Who true to Liberty, her standard rear'd,</br>Despis'd the tamp'ring of a courtly feast,</br>Nor ministerial despotism fear'd.
Let not ambition mock the city toil,</br>Their thrifty joys — and happiness obscure,</br>Nor barter fancied freedom for a smile,</br>Nor arbitrary insolence endure.
The boast of civil rule — the Lord mayor's power,</br>And all that wealth to Aldermen e'er gave,</br>Await alike the desolating hour,</br>Great Guildhall's grandees sink into the grave.
Virtues, to all, shou'd monuments impute,</br>Tho senseless stone must needs be taught to lie,</br>For can just praises H—'s actions suit,</br>Who cou'd the laws of liberty defy:
Can fallacies in prose or verse recall,</br>A custard-eating Alderman to life,</br>To talk of politics, or stuff at hall,</br>Prescribe to statesmen, and submit to wife.
For thee, who of the known, or unknown dead,</br>Doth (insignificantly) tales relate:</br>Prompted by whim, should some grave cit be led,</br>And wish to know the story of thy fate:
Happy some former intimate may say,</br>"Oft have I seen him at the peep of dawn,</br>From some lewd brothel take his weary way,</br>Sick of the harlots who for payment fawn.
"At Weatherby's and Murphy's often times,</br>With wine elated, have I known him be,</br>To trace out objects for politic rhymes,</br>And there reflected till he could not see.
"Maudlin, by morning then he'd homeward steer,</br>And bravely beat each post that crost his path,</br>Secur'd with wine, and liberty from fear,</br>Defy the ministerial men of Lath.
"One morn I miss'd him at th' accustom'd place,</br>I sought another, and another still,</br>In no old haunt could I his footsteps trace,</br>So drank a chearful bumper, and sate still.
"Next day, by bucks, in sable garments clad,</br>Towards the church I saw him slowly borne:</br>The scene, I must confess, was wondrous sad,</br>To see the maudlin libertinians mourn."
Upon his grave, in each revolving year,</br>To drink a bumper they by oath are bound:</br>Give Wilkes, Glynn, Horne, and Liberty a chear,</br>And pray that Heaven may all their foes confound.</br>
